definition: A protocol for communication between a client and a server over the internet. It stands for Hypertext Transfer Protocol.
An HTTP message sent by a client to a server to initiate an action. It contains information about the resource being requested and the method of accessing it.
An HTTP message sent by a server to a client in response to a request. It contains information about the status of the request and the requested resource.
An HTTP message component that contains information about the message, such as the content type, encoding, and length.
An HTTP message component that contains the data being sent in the message, such as the content of a web page or the data being submitted in a form.
An HTTP method used to retrieve information from a server. It is one of the most commonly used HTTP methods.
An HTTP method used to submit data to a server to create or update a resource. It is commonly used for form submissions and API requests.
An HTTP method used to update an existing resource on a server. It replaces the existing resource with the updated data.
An HTTP method used to delete a resource on a server.
A three-digit code returned by a server in an HTTP response that indicates the status of the request. Examples include 200 OK, 404 Not Found, and 500 Internal Server Error.
An HTTP header that specifies the type of data being sent in the message body, such as text, HTML, or JSON.
A string that identifies the location of a resource on the internet. It stands for Uniform Resource Locator.
A key-value pair in a URL that is used to pass data to a server. It is typically used for filtering or sorting data.
The data returned by a server in an HTTP response. It is typically in the form of text, HTML, or JSON.
The data sent by a client to a server in an HTTP request. It is typically in the form of text, HTML, or JSON.
The process of verifying the identity of a user or system. It is commonly used to control access to resources on a server.
The process of granting or denying access to a resource on a server. It is typically based on the identity of the user or system making the request.
A URL that represents a specific resource or action on a server. It is typically associated with a specific HTTP method, such as GET or POST.
A lightweight data interchange format that is easy for humans to read and write and easy for machines to parse and generate. It stands for JavaScript Object Notation.
A markup language used for encoding documents in a format that is both human-readable and machine-readable. It stands for Extensible Markup Language.
